subject: RE: [junit] Comparing arrays in JUnit 4
msgSnippet: I don t think writing all 162 versions of assertEquals is necessary, but I do think writing assertEquals for arrays of all primitive types (when expected and
messageBody:
I don't think writing all 162 versions of assertEquals is necessary, but I do think writing assertEquals for arrays of all primitive types (when expected and actual are arrays of the same type) is useful. I put together an expansion for JUnit 3.8.1 that has these and also assertions for Collections (ordered and unordered), Readers, and InputStreams. I'd sure like to see the standard JUnit supply all of these.

..David..


________________________________

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Elliotte Harold
Sent: Tuesday, August 23, 2005 8:17 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Comparing arrays in JUnit 4


Using the new array compare method this test case fails:

@Test public void testArrayCompare() {
int[] a = {1, 2, 3};
int[] b = {1, 2, 3};
assertEquals(a, b);

}

However this one succeeds:

@Test public void testArrayCompare() {
Object[] a = {1, 2, 3};
Object[] b = {1, 2, 3};
assertEquals(a, b);

}

This is a compile time error:

@Test public void testArrayCompare() {
int[] a = {1, 2, 3};
int[] b = {1, 2, 3};
assertEquals((Object[]) a, (Object[]) b);

}


This test case also fails:

@Test public void testArrayCompare() {
int[] a = {1, 2, 3};
int[] b = {1, 2, 3};
assertEquals((Object) a, (Object) b);

}


Short of adding 162 different methods to compare each and every possible
combination of arrays (something I would not rule out but it certainly
wouldn't be my first choice) does anyone see a reasonable way to use
Java 5 autoboxing to allow arrays of primitive data types to be compared?

--
